name: Atlanta
fun_fact: Fun fact: Paschal's Restaurant was the unofficial headquarters of the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960sâ€”Martin Luther King Jr., John Lewis, and Andrew Young planned protests over fried chicken and sweet tea, making it both a soul food institution and a piece of American history.

hero_dishes.name: Fried Chicken at The Busy Bee Cafe
hero_dishes.description: Perfectly seasoned, crispy-skinned fried chicken that's been made the same way since 1947â€”juicy, golden, and everything Southern comfort food should be
hero_dishes.origin_story: Founded by Lucy 'Momma Lucy' Jackson in 1947, The Busy Bee earned a James Beard 'America's Classics' award and a Michelin Guide Bib Gourmand (2023-2024). Momma Lucy's self-taught recipes became Atlanta legend
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Busy Bee Cafe (been serving since 1947), Mary Mac's Tea Room (since 1945, called 'Atlanta's Dining Room' by the state legislature)

hero_dishes.name: Fried Catfish at Paschal's
hero_dishes.description: Cornmeal-crusted catfish fried to a golden crisp, served with hot sauce and collard greensâ€”classic soul food with a side of history
hero_dishes.origin_story: Paschal's opened in 1947 in Castleberry Hill and became the gathering place for Civil Rights leaders. The restaurant's soul food literally fueled the movement. Six decades later, it's still serving the same recipes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Paschal's (Historic Castleberry Hill)â€”civil rights landmark since 1947

hero_dishes.name: Modern Global Soul Food at Twisted Soul Cookhouse & Pours
hero_dishes.description: Chef Deborah VanTrece's contemporary take on soul foodâ€”think oxtails with Asian spices or jerk chicken with Caribbean heat
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef VanTrece, a former flight attendant and bestselling cookbook author, created 'modern global soul food' by combining Southern traditions with flavors from her worldwide travels. Twisted Soul earned a 2024 Michelin Guide recommendation
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Twisted Soul Cookhouse & Pours (W. Midtown Atlanta)

hero_dishes.name: Fried Green Tomatoes at Mary Mac's Tea Room
hero_dishes.description: Cornmeal-crusted green tomatoes fried until crispy and tangy, served with remoulade sauceâ€”a Southern classic done right
hero_dishes.origin_story: Mary Mac's has been Atlanta's dining room since 1945. Governors, celebrities, and college students all fill the same tables for Southern staples. The restaurant's dedication to traditional recipes made it a state-recognized institution
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mary Mac's Tea Room (Ponce de Leon)â€”officially Atlanta's Dining Room since 1945

signature_drinks.name: Sweet Tea
signature_drinks.description: Ice-cold black tea sweetened to the point of near-syrupâ€”the unofficial beverage of the South
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in huge glasses with meals at every soul food restaurant. The sweetness is non-negotiable; unsweetened tea is considered heresy. Refills are free and expected

signature_drinks.name: Coca-Cola
signature_drinks.description: Atlanta's most famous exportâ€”the birthplace of Coke means it flows like water here
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always Coke, never Pepsi. Born in Atlanta in 1886, locals take pride in drinking it ice-cold from the fountain. The World of Coca-Cola museum is a pilgrimage site

food_culture_notes: Soul food in Atlanta is inseparable from Civil Rights historyâ€”restaurants like Paschal's were movement headquarters
Mary Mac's Tea Room is so iconic the Georgia state legislature officially named it 'Atlanta's Dining Room'
Three restaurants have Michelin recognition (Busy Bee, Twisted Soul)â€”soul food is fine dining here
Old Lady Gang (owned by Real Housewife Kandi Burruss) brings celebrity culture to traditional Southern cooking
